subject: Re: [junit] ThreadLocal
msgSnippet: A common pattern we use with our web apps is this. - Factories manage the creation of resources for the next level down (e.g., web tier - EJB tier, EJB tier
messageBody:
A common pattern we use with our web apps is this.

- Factories manage the creation of resources for the next level down (e.g.,
web tier -> EJB tier, EJB tier -> integration tier)

- Classes that need to access/instantiate resources in a lower layer (e.g.,
an EJB that needs a DB connection) take a factory object at construction
time.

- The factories are configured at runtime using simple java property files
(e.g., use.database=true, use.ejbs=false)

- Test code can configure factories using parameters (e.g., testFactory =
new DataSourceFactory(false) . . . ) and pass these factories in to the
object(s) under test.

This allows us to ensure that tests always use the mock objects, without
"cluttering" the production code with lots of conditional logic or extra
method parameters.

Jeff Nielsen
Digital Focus
www.digitalfocus.com

From: "David Corbin" <dcorbin@...>
To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Monday, March 24, 2003 8:09 AM
Subject: Re: [junit] ThreadLocal


> Jason Rogers wrote:
>
> >On Sun, 23 Mar 2003 14:23:30 -0500, "David Corbin"
> ><dcorbin@...> said:
> >
> >
> >> I'm getting tired of having to pass some objects through 6-8 methods,
> >> and it's making method signatures very ugly.
> >> The question is, what do folks think about using ThreadLocal to
create
> >> "per request singleton-like" objects. By using a common
base
> >> TestCase,
> >> I could set up the TLS easily enough without overburdening the unit
> >> tests, I think.
> >> David
> >>
> >>
> >
> >I think was you are sensing is a "code smell."
> >
> There's no doubt about that. It's a question of how to solve the smell.
>
> > I don't have an opinion
> >about the TLS you mentioned but I would suggest using this "pain" to
> >force yourself to refactor some more. For instance, you could use
> >Factories, Delegators|Facades, or Proxies instead polluting your API with
> >unneeded args.
> >
> >
> <snip>
>
> >In some cases, that may be the thing to do, in
> >others however it makes more sense for the object you are testing to have
> >those things implicitly available -- your situation sounds a lot like the
> >latter.
> >
> >
> Well, as near as I can tell there are 4 choices on how something is made
> available:
>
> 1) at construction
> 2) as an argument
> 3) as a global/singleton
> 4) as ThreadLocal (similar to #3, but more flexible, certainly in the
> web environment)
>
> #2 is what I've been doing, and has created the smell
> #1 generally doesn't work well, because the "something" may not be very
> tightly bound to the object being constucted.
> That leaves #3 and #4. I have a long-standing global-phobia. Perhaps
> it's too strong. #4 of course, isn't that differrent from #3 ( think of
> them as semi-global).
>
> Have a missed a choice?
>
> David.
